└┴┘└─┘┴─┘└─┘└─┘┴ ┴└─┘   ┴ └─┘  └─┘└─┘┴└─┴┴   ┴ ┴└─ o ┴└─┘   ┴ └─┘┴└─┴ ┴┴┘└┘┴ ┴┴─┘

Terminal provides a rich set of commands for invoking endpoints using different protocols and options and displays a more readable formatting of JSON responses and logs (generated using the log module). It is a very useful scriptr.io debugging tool.

Terminal can be used with multiple scriptr.io servers and accounts by changing the url and token. By default, both are set to the hosting account's url and anonymous token. Use the set command to change them.

type help to find available commands.

Use "help [comand name]" to display specific info about a command. Available commands are:

{{ commands }}

If a command is not recognized, the terminal will assume it's a <script name> and will HTTP POST <script name> to scriptr.io. The syntax of a POST command is assumed for the remaining arguments.

Duh!
invokes a scriptr.io endpoint by using a websocket connection

parameters:
 -p <JSON>:	request params
 -nolog:	don't show logs
 -noresponse:	don't show response

example:
ws my/script -params {"humidity": "33", "temp": "22"} -noresponse -nolog
invokes a scriptr.io endpoint by using HTTP {{ method }}.

parameters:
 -p <JSON>:	request params
 -h <JSON>:	request headers
 -nolog:	don't show logs
 -noresponse:	don't show response
 -repeat N:	repeat call N times and display average/min/max execution times [NOT IMPLEMENTED]

example:
{{ method }} my/script -params {"humidity": "33", "temp": "22"} -header {"header1":"value1"} -noresponse -nolog -repeat 10
lists scripts available on the account
Sets various terminal options. 


usage:
set <variable>=<value>.

Type set to see available variables.
invokes an mqtt endpoint
Shows history of typed commands.
  -clear: deletes history
{{ timestamp }} {{ level }} {{ message }}
